_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Blanc Vineyards Plant 2 has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 Blanc Vineyards Plant 2, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Blanc Vineyards Plant 2 has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name                | Process Chemical              | Process Quantity(lbs.)

Ammonia Refrigeration         Anhydrous Ammonia               43,000



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.



Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM regulation to meet CalARP and

RMP obligations as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Description



Facility Overview

Blanc Vineyards Plant 2 operates a commercial cold storage for grapes in Delano, CA. The facility has an ammonia refrigeration system that provides refrigeration capacity to the following:

(5) Rooms

(3) Precools



Facility Location

Blanc Vineyards Plant 2 is located at 13938 Avenue 16, Delano, CA 93215. The latitude and longitude of the high pressure receiver is 35.820413, -119.260581. The facility is located approximately 500 feet west of state highway 99 in a rural area surrounded primarily by agriculture land.



Flood Hazards

According to FEMA Flood Map Service, the facility is located in "an area of minimal flood hazard".



Seismic Susceptibility

Blanc Vineyards Plant 2 is not located in an Alquist-Priolo Fault Zone as defined by the California Department of Conservation. In addition, a review of United States Geological Survey (USGS) fault maps showed that faults within close proximity are not considered high risk:

Pond Fault - <150 Years

Poso Creek Fault - <1,600,000 Years

Unnamed Fault Near Rag Gulch- <1,600,000 Years

The USGS 2018 One-Year Model revealed that Blanc Vineyards Plant 1 has a 1-2% chance of experiencing "potentially minor-damage" due to ground shaking in 2018.



Description of Covered Process



Pumped Overfeed System



The refrigerated areas are equipped with air-cooling evaporators which are supplied from recirculators as required for pumped overfeed operation.



Most control valve groups are located inside the machinery room or directly outside the associated refrigerated room  to provide easy access. The refrigera

tion machinery is contained within or directly above the machinery room. 



Process Chemistry



The refrigeration system employed at Blanc Vineyards Plant 2 is configured for pumped overfeed operation. The function and thermodynamics of each major component type in the system is summarized below:



High Pressure Receivers

The purpose of the high pressure receivers is to provide a safe location to add and store high pressure liquid ammonia in the refrigeration system. The high pressure receivers receive high pressure liquid from the condenser and supply high pressure liquid to each recirculator and liquid injection cooling to the screw compressor. The high pressure receivers are also used to provide storage for ammonia not being used in the process at any given moment. High Pressure Receiver 1 is equipped with a main liquid feed shut-off valve (king valve) that is clearly labeled and can be used to stop the flow of ammonia throughout the system. Under normal conditions, the high pressure receivers contain high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



High Temperature Recirculators

The purpose of the high temperature recirculators is to provide a supply of low pressure liquid that can be used in high temperature evaporators throughout the facility. The high temperature recirculators receive liquid from High Pressure Receiver 1 and supply, by gravity, low pressure liquid to the ammonia pumps mounted underneath the supplying vessel. Liquid and vapor returned from the evaporators is separated inside the recirculators to allow only the vapor to be piped to the suction of each high stage compressor. The high temperature recirculators are each equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors. Under normal conditions, the high temperature recirculators contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Air-Cooling Evaporators (Pumped Overfeed)

The purpose of the air-cooling evaporators is to remove heat from the air in order to maintain a predetermined space temperature. The air-cooling evaporators receive liquid from the recirculators. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporators use an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it returns to the supplying vessel. Under normal conditions, the air-cooling evaporators contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Compressors

The purpose of the compressors is to raise the temperature and pressure of the low pressure gas in order to reject the heat absorbed in the evaporator to the atmosphere. The compressors receive low pressure vapor from the recirculators and discharge high pressure vapor to the evaporative condensers. The compressors are equipped with high discharge pressure cutouts to shut the equipment off if the pressure exceeds the setpoint. Under normal conditions, the compressors contain both high and low pressure vapor ammonia.



Evaporative Condenser

The purpose of the evaporative condenser is to reject the heat absorbed in the evaporators to the atmosphere. The evaporative condenser receives high pressure, superheated vapor from the compressors and supplies high pressure liquid to the high pressure receivers. The condenser uses air and water to cool the warm ammonia as it passes through a series of tubes within the condenser. As the cooling medium of air and water draws the heat from the vapor, the refrigerant condenses into a liquid and flows to the high pressure receivers. Under normal conditions, the evaporative condenser contains high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.

Safety Systems



Ammonia Detection System

The machinery room and each refrigeration room is equipped with an ammonia detector. A Sherlock Panel provides central monitoring of ammonia detection and alerts personnel if the ammonia concentration exceeds 25 ppm. Audible/visual alarms are available inside and outside  the machinery room. If the concentration reaches 25 ppm, the emergency ventilation system will be activated. Once the ammonia concentration reaches 450 ppm, the compressors in the machinery room will be de-energized.



Relief Valves

All ASME pressure vessels and positive displacement compressors are equipped with relief valves designed to relieve pressure and protect the equipment from rupturing. Details regarding the relief valves are summarized below:

Each relief valve has a set pressure equal to or less than the MAWP of the equipment that the relief valve protects;

Each relief valve has a capacity which meets or exceeds the requirement of ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Addendum A ?15.3.8;

All relief valves terminate to the atmosphere, 7.25 ft above the roof;

Select relief valve assemblies are equipped with a relief vent indicator (RVI) to assist in recognizing that an overpressure event has occurred. Indicator flags are mounted to the shaft of the RVI on the outside of the housing. A paddle is set such that any sudden flow in the relief vent line pushes it down simultaneously raising the flags which then provide a clear signal that a relief valve has lifted. Stoppers mounted to the exterior prevent the flag/shaft from rotating more than the 90? swing.



Screw Compressor Safety Devices

Each screw compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment. The following list summarizes the safety devices built into each screw compressor package:

High Discharge Pressure Cutout - The high discharge pressure cutout, will shut down the compressor if the discharge pressure equals or exceeds the setpoint.

Low Suction Pressur

e Cutout - The low suction pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the suction pressure is equal to or less than the setpoint.

Oil Pressure Cutout - The oil pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil pressure equals or deviates below the setpoint.

High Oil Temperature Cutout - The high oil temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil temperature equals or exceeds the setpoint.

Low Oil Temperature Cutout - The low oil temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil temperature equals or falls below the setpoint.

Discharge Temperature Cutout - The high discharge temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the discharge temperature equals or exceeds the setpoint.



Reciprocating Compressor Safety Devices

Each reciprocating compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment. The following list summarizes the safety devices built into each compressor package:

High Discharge Pressure Cutout - The high discharge pressure cutout, will shut down the compressor if the discharge pressure equals or exceeds the setpoint.

Low Suction Pressure Cutout - The low suction pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the suction pressure is equal to or less than the setpoint.

Oil Pressure Cutout - The oil pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil pressure equals or exceeds the setpoint.



High Level Float Switches

The liquid recirculators are each equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high liquid level in the vessel. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors.



Level Controller

The Liquid Recirculator 1 is equipped with a level controller to control the liquid ammonia level in the vessel. The level controller is equipped with high level, control level, and low level set points.



Main Liquid Feed Shut-Off Valve (King Valve)

The High Pressure Receiver 1 is equipped with a sin

gle main liquid feed shut-off valve (king valve) that is clearly labeled and can be used to stop the flow of ammonia throughout the system.



Emergency Refrigeration Switch (E-Stop)

The principal entrance to the machinery room is equipped with an emergency refrigeration switch (e-stop) that controls power to the refrigeration machinery inside the machinery room. The switch can be activated in an emergency using the hammer next to the switch to break the switch glass.



Process Classification



The ammonia refrigeration system at Blanc Vineyards Plant 2 consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. As such, the refrigeration system at Blanc Vineyards Plant 2 is treated as a single process.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Blanc Vineyards Plant 2 has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration process at the Blanc Vineyards Plant 2 facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep records of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked

frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 



1.4 Five Year Accident History



Blanc Vineyards Plant 2 has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Blanc Vineyards Plant 2's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

Cal/OSHA's Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR ?3220

U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38

Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 8 CCR ?5189(n)

U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements]- Title 29 CFR ?1910.119(n)

California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 ?2765.1-2765.2

USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR ?68.95

California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 ?2731

California "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 8 CCR Title 8 ?5192(q)

Federal "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 29 CFR ?1910.120(q)



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Blanc Vineyards Plant 2 has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Blanc Vineyards Plant 2 continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP

-PSM program. This has improved Blanc Vineyards Plant 2's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Blanc Vineyards Plant 2's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.



Blanc Vineyards Plant 2 has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.

In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Blanc Vineyards Plant 2 has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.



For the future, Blanc Vineyards Plant 2 now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Blanc Vineyards Plant 2 employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Blanc Vineyards Plant 2 will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
